Topic.Title: Watch Friday near close time. Market maker

Message.Msg: Today, Thursday, the open interest of the Aug $26 put options is 29,317. That means that after the 12k trading volume in $26 Aug puts, the open interest increased from 23,914 to 29,317 or about 5.4k. The combinations of the 12k BUY/SELL to OPEN/CLOSE transactions on these options only affected the open interest by 5.4k. How did that happen? The answer is much more complex than "there is some put volume so the market makers are going to xxxx". Those put options could possibly be part of a multiple option trade where a combination of put and call options were made at the same time.

Topic.Title: Intel should have already bought Nvidia

Message.Msg: Gaming will never die. Agreed. Gaming PC's will never die. Agreed. Gamers want Nvidia. I have a doubts about this statement. I think a gamer would choose the best (performance, support, ....) solution within his price range. Even if I agreed with you about gamers wanting NVDA, I don't see why Intel would want to own them. I don't know who Intel is negotiating to buy but I doubt that it is NVDA. I don't know what Intel needs to widen the road to the lower end devices. Or maybe the next link in their security roadmap. They are working on something. RIMM $4b market cap. NOK $10b market cap. IDCC $1.4b NVDA $9b ????

Topic.Title: Watch Friday near close time. Market maker

Message.Msg: IMO, interpreting option trades/volume is tough. There are a couple clues that I think the retail investor can guess at but it is very hard to figure motivation. I look at the IMPLIED VOLATILITY to see if someone is BUYING (higher premium & IV) or SELLING (LOWER premium & IV). I can also look at the BID and ASK "SIZE" or how many are available at the BID/ASK price. High size implies the side of the trade. If today, there was 1,000,000 Aug $26 put options trade, would that be bullish or bearish? Most would say bearish. If the open interest tomorrow was unchanged, it means someone churned the trades ... buying and selling for a net position of zero. What does that mean? If the open interest tomorrow was increased by 1,000,000, did I BUY to OPEN 1,000,000 put option contracts? Or did I SELL to OPEN 1,000,000 put contracts. If I bought them, ... am I long shares and looking for insurance? or am I just bearish looking for appreciation on a put trade? If I sold them, .... am I looking for income when they drop in price as the share price goes up, or am I expecting INTC to finish above $26 and they will expire worthless? or am do I expect them to finish worthless but having the shares PUT to me is fine? Much more ....

Topic.Title: Apple's A6

Message.Msg: The one thing that has consistently spelled trouble for PC growth rates has been a worldwide recession. But with the growth of the sales of iPads people tend to associate it with cause and effect. I went in search of the Nexus 7 yesterday. Best Buy who had previously sworn that they would get the Nexus 7 was now saying they won't be stocking it. Over at Costco the tablet isle was a ghost town. For those who are wanting better than a smart phone experience on a tablet have slim pickings. People who would buy their kids a Nintendo 3DS buy the iPad. People who want to watch Family Guy on a larger mobile screen by the iPad. People who want to run their calendar and browse e-mails on a larger screen than a smart phone buy an iPad. People who want a computer buy a computer. PC=Production Tablet=Consumption

Topic.Title: Watch Friday near close time. Market maker

Message.Msg: I've got some sept 27 calls that are currently underwater. My fear is that INTC drops to ~$26 tomorrow and my greed says INTC will rise in the next 37 days. Currently I'm watching, hanging & worrying.

Topic.Title: Watch Friday near close time. Market maker

Message.Msg: All I have left is short some $28 Oct puts. I have rolled them a couple times so I am down on price but have booked a couple credits. I usually sell puts out 60-90 days at the money (highest premium) when they trade at $1-$1.50. I do it after Intel has several down days in a row and VIX is up so the odds are higher for a rebound. I like selling the puts because they have some of the dividend baked into the premium. Buying the calls is cheaper for the same dividend reason. When the premium drops to a dime over intrinsic value, I roll them out a couple months in the future for a credit.
